content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Maria Lopez: I was born in Seville, Spain, but I moved to the United States when I was just five years old with my mother and younger brother. My father left us when I was very young, and my mother worked long hours to support us. We lived in a small apartment in a working-class neighborhood, and money was always tight. I remember walking to school with my brother, sometimes skipping meals so we could afford school supplies. My mother never had the chance to finish high school, and she always encouraged me to do better. I worked part-time at a local store after school to help out, but I was determined to get my education. I moved to Miami when I was sixteen, and it was a big change for me. I had to adjust to a new culture, a new language, and a new way of life. I graduated high school and went on to earn my bachelor's degree in business administration. I married my husband, Carlos, a few years ago, and we've been working hard to build a better life for our family. It hasn't been easy, but I believe in perseverance and faith.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Maria Lopez: Yes, there was a moment that changed everything for me. When I turned sixteen, my mother had to move us to Miami because the job opportunities in the small town we were living in were limited, and she wanted a better future for us. It was a difficult decision because I had to leave behind the only home I had ever known, my friends, and the few memories I had of my father. Moving to Miami was overwhelming. I didn't speak English well, and I felt like an outsider in every way. But I remember one specific day—my first day at a new high school in Miami. I was so nervous, and I almost didn't go. My mother had to physically take me to the school, and I cried the entire way there. But once I walked into that classroom, I saw a teacher who looked at me with kindness, not judgment. Her name was Mrs. Thompson, and she stayed after class to help me with my English. That moment made me realize that I had a choice: I could let fear and loneliness define me, or I could push through and take control of my future. I chose the latter. I worked harder in school, joined the school's business club, and eventually earned a scholarship to a local university. That crossroads—standing in that classroom, scared and unsure—was the turning point. It taught me that even in the darkest moments, there is always a way forward if you're willing to take it.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Maria Lopez: I think it was a conscious choice, even if I didn't realize it at the time. I had to make a decision every single day after moving to Miami—whether to stay in my shell or to try again. I remember one day, after struggling with a math test, I sat in the library for hours, crying, feeling like I would never catch up. But then I thought about my mother, how she had sacrificed everything for me, and I knew I couldn't let her down. That was when I decided I would not just survive, but thrive. I started going to extra help sessions, I asked questions even when I was embarrassed, and I made it a point to learn English outside of class too. It wasn't just about getting good grades—it was about proving to myself that I had the strength to overcome adversity. I think that moment in the classroom with Mrs. Thompson was the spark, but the fire was something I had to keep stoking every day. I chose to believe in myself, and that choice shaped the person I am today.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Maria Lopez: Absolutely. I think if someone had reached out to me when I first arrived in Miami, it could have made a huge difference. I remember feeling so lost, not just because of the language barrier but because I didn't know how to navigate the system—how to get help with school, how to find resources for my family. I think organizations that support immigrants, or even teachers like Mrs. Thompson who took the time to help me, were lifelines. I also think my mother was my biggest support system. She didn't have much, but she never gave up on me. I know there are people out there who are struggling just like I did, and I wish there were more programs to help them feel seen and supported. Sometimes, all it takes is one person to believe in you when you can't believe in yourself.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Maria Lopez: Yes, I have a partner and two children. My husband, Carlos, is a mechanic, and he's been my rock since the day we met. We met at a community center in Miami, actually—both of us were volunteering for a local outreach program that helps immigrants. He's from Colombia, and he had his own struggles when he first arrived in the U.S. We bonded over our shared experiences, and we've been married for six years now. We have a daughter, Sofia, who's eight, and a son, Mateo, who's five. They're both bilingual, which I'm very proud of, and they're growing up in a home where we value education, hard work, and faith. My mother still lives in Miami, and though we don't see each other as often as I'd like, she's always there for us. I try to be the kind of mother I never had—supportive, encouraging, and always reminding them that they can achieve anything if they're willing to put in the effort. It's not always easy, but I wouldn't trade this life for anything.

Going through those interview questions felt like revisiting the different chapters of my life, each one revealing how far I've come and the strength it took to get here. Talking about my childhood reminded me of the sacrifices my mother made and the resilience she passed down to me. Reflecting on that crossroads in Miami brought back the fear and uncertainty I felt, but also the moment I chose to fight for my future. It was humbling to acknowledge how much I relied on the support of others, like Mrs. Thompson and my mother, and how their belief in me helped me believe in myself. Sharing about my family now fills me with gratitude and hope, knowing that I'm giving my children the same values and opportunities that were so important to me. It's amazing how much one person's journey can be shaped by choices, support, and perseverance.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Maria Lopez: My brother, Javier, is still in Spain with my mother. He's ten years younger than me, and we've always had a close bond, even though we haven't seen each other in over a decade. He's a quiet, thoughtful person, and he's been working in construction back home. I know it's not easy for him either, but I'm proud of him for staying strong. We talk on the phone whenever we can, and I make sure to keep him updated on our lives here. I hope one day he'll be able to visit us in the U.S., maybe even join us. I also have a cousin, Ana, who moved to Miami a few years ago. She's a nurse, and she's been a great friend to me—someone I can talk to about everything, from parenting struggles to my own fears about the future. I feel lucky to have people in my life who care about me, even from afar. Family is everything to me, and I know that no matter where we are, we're all connected by the same hopes and dreams.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Maria Lopez: Yes, there are a few friends who have been important to me along the way. One of them is Rosa, a neighbor from when I first moved to Miami. She was one of the first people to welcome me into the community, and she helped me navigate the challenges of starting over. She's a single mother too, and we've supported each other through the ups and downs of raising kids while working full-time. She's like a sister to me. Then there's Luis, who was my best friend in college. We met in the business club, and he became one of my closest confidants. He's now a financial advisor, and he's always been there to offer advice, whether it's about my career or my family. I also have a few coworkers at the store where I work now—people like Elena and Tomás, who have become like family. They've been there for me during tough times, and I know I can count on them. Friends have always been a source of strength for me, especially when I needed someone to remind me that I wasn't alone in this journey.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Maria Lopez: I live in a neighborhood in Miami called Coral Gables. It's a mix of old and new—there are these beautiful historic homes with big lawns and Spanish tile roofs, but there are also newer apartments and condos where a lot of families like mine live. It's a pretty safe area, and there are plenty of parks and community centers where kids can play and parents can meet. I love that there are so many different cultures here, and you can hear Spanish, English, and other languages spoken in the streets. My apartment is in one of the newer buildings, and it's not too far from the store where I work. I like that I can walk to the grocery store, the school where my kids go, and even the local church. It's a tight-knit community, and I've made a lot of friends here. There's always someone to talk to, whether it's the neighbor who waters my plants when I'm at work or the barista at the coffee shop who knows my order by heart. It's not perfect—sometimes the traffic can be a nightmare, and the cost of living is high—but it feels like home to me. I like knowing that my kids are growing up in a place where they can be themselves, where they can dream big, and where they can feel safe and supported.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Maria Lopez: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. There's a sense of community that makes a big difference. I know most of my neighbors by name, and they know me too. If something were ever wrong, I know someone would look out for us. That said, I'm not naive—I know there are parts of Miami that aren't as safe, especially at night. So I try to be cautious, like any parent would. I make sure my kids are home before dark, and I always keep the doors locked. But overall, I feel secure in this neighborhood. It's not just the physical safety, though. It's the feeling that people care about each other, that there's a shared responsibility to look out for one another. That, to me, is just as important as the locks on the doors.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Maria Lopez: Living here has had its challenges, but I wouldn't trade it for anything. The cost of living is definitely a strain—rent, groceries, school supplies, and everything else adds up. Sometimes I have to make tough choices, like whether to buy new clothes for the kids or save up for something else. But I also love the opportunities that come with being in a place like Coral Gables. My kids have access to good schools, and I feel like I'm part of a community that values education and hard work. There are also cultural events, festivals, and places to celebrate our heritage, which is important to me. I know that not everyone has the same opportunities, but I try to focus on what we do have and how we can make the most of it. It's not always easy, but I believe that with faith, family, and a little bit of perseverance, we can build a better life here.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has evolved over the years. Talking about my husband, children, and extended family reminded me of the love and support that have been constant in my life, even during the toughest times. It also made me realize how important it is to be present for my own kids, to give them the same opportunities and values that were so crucial for me. When I described my neighborhood, I felt a deep sense of gratitude for the community I now call home. It's not perfect, but it's safe, welcoming, and full of people who care. I think that's what makes it feel like home—not just the place, but the people in it. I'm proud of the life I've built, and I hope my children grow up knowing how much love and hard work went into creating it.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Maria Lopez: My days are pretty consistent, but there's always something different happening depending on the day of the week. On weekdays, I wake up early—usually around 5:30 or 6—so I can get my kids ready for school before heading to work. My husband usually takes the kids to school, but I help out on days when he's working late. I work full time at a local store, so my days are pretty busy. After work, I pick up the kids, have dinner with the family, and then I try to spend some time helping with homework or just talking to them about their day. On weekends, we like to go to the park, visit the library, or have a family movie night. I also try to set aside time for myself, whether it's going to Mass on Sunday or just sitting down with a cup of coffee and reading the paper. Life is full, but I wouldn't trade this routine for anything—it's what keeps me grounded and connected to the people I love.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Maria Lopez: I work full time at a local grocery store, which is just a few blocks away from my apartment. I start my shift at 7:00 a.m., and I usually work until 3:30 p.m. It's a demanding job—there's a lot of standing, lifting, and organizing—but I've come to appreciate the rhythm of it. I enjoy the people I work with, and I find comfort in the fact that I'm providing for my family. I've been there for almost three years now, and it's become a second home in a way. Some days are harder than others, especially when the hours are long and the stress of balancing work and family life feels overwhelming. But I remind myself that this job is more than just a paycheck—it's a way to give my children the stability they deserve. I also take on some extra shifts on weekends when I can, just to help with the bills. It's not glamorous, but it's fulfilling, and I'm proud of the work I do.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Maria Lopez: Yes, there are a few other things that fill my days. I try to make time for my faith every morning, even if it's just a few minutes of prayer before getting the kids ready. I also have a small garden on my balcony where I grow herbs and a few vegetables—my mother taught me how to do that back in Spain, and it's something I miss. It's a small way to connect with my roots and feel grounded. I also take care of my mother's medications and help her with errands when I can, even though we don't see each other often. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I know that these little routines help me stay focused and give me a sense of purpose. I think that's what keeps me going—knowing that every small effort I make is for my family and for the life I'm building for them.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Maria Lopez: Well, recently, I started taking evening classes at the community college to work toward my master's in business. It's been a big change for me, balancing work, family, and school, but I feel like it's a step toward something bigger. I've been going to class twice a week after work, and it's been challenging—sometimes I'm exhausted by the time I get home, and I have to be careful not to let the kids see how stressed I am. But I've also found a new sense of purpose in it. My husband has been incredibly supportive, even though he doesn't always understand why I need to go back to school. He just knows that I want more for our family, and that gives me strength. I've also started mentoring a few young women at the store who are trying to get their feet on the ground, just like I did. It feels good to give back, to be that person who someone else can look up to. I know it's not easy, but I believe that every step I take, no matter how small, is helping shape the future I want for my children.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Maria Lopez: On a typical weekday during the school year, my kids have a pretty structured routine. They wake up around 7:00 a.m., and after a quick breakfast, they get ready for school. My daughter, Sofia, is in third grade, and my son, Mateo, is in kindergarten. Sofia usually has a packed lunch, while Mateo eats the school-provided meals. After school, Sofia has aftercare at the school for a couple of hours, where she does homework and plays with her friends. She also takes piano lessons on Tuesdays and Thursdays, which she really enjoys. Mateo has a shorter day, so he comes home around 3:00 p.m., and we have a snack before heading to the park or the library. On Wednesdays, we have family dinner at my mother's house, which is a special treat for the kids. I try to make sure they have time to play, rest, and spend time with each other. It's not always perfect, but I believe that consistency and love are what help them grow into strong, confident kids.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has evolved over the years. Talking about my husband, children, and extended family reminded me of the love and support that have been constant in my life, even during the toughest times. It also made me realize how important it is to be present for my own kids, to give them the same opportunities and values that were so crucial for me. When I described my neighborhood, I felt a deep sense of gratitude for the community I now call home. It's not perfect, but it's safe, welcoming, and full of people who care. I think that's what makes it feel like home—not just the place, but the people in it. I'm proud of the life I've built, and I hope my children grow up knowing how much love and hard work went into creating it.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Maria Lopez: My health has been mostly good, though I've had my share of challenges. I used to struggle with stress-related issues, especially when I was first starting out in Miami, juggling work, school, and taking care of my family. I remember feeling exhausted all the time, and I didn't take care of myself the way I should have. But over the years, I've learned to prioritize my well-being. I try to eat healthy, even if it's not always easy with a busy schedule. I make sure to include fruits and vegetables in our meals, and I try to cook at home as much as possible. I also take walks with the kids whenever I can—it's not just good for them, but it helps me clear my mind too. I started going to the local clinic for regular check-ups after my doctor encouraged me to be more proactive. I also take some medication for high blood pressure, which I was diagnosed with a few years ago. It's a reminder that I need to take care of myself, not just for my family, but for me too. I've also started practicing mindfulness and prayer more regularly, which helps me stay grounded. I know I'm not perfect, but I'm doing my best to be healthy, both physically and emotionally, so I can be there for my kids and my family.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Maria Lopez: What makes it easy to stay healthy is knowing that my family depends on me, and that gives me the motivation to take care of myself. I also find comfort in my faith, and I try to pray or meditate even if it's just for a few minutes each day. But what makes it hard is the constant stress of balancing everything—work, school, family responsibilities. There are days when I feel like I don't have time to eat properly or get enough rest. I've had to learn to be more intentional about self-care, like setting aside time for a walk or a quiet moment to breathe. I also struggle with the temptation to skip meals or rely on fast food when I'm short on time. But I remind myself that small changes add up, and that my health is just as important as my kids' or my husband's. I'm still learning, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself in the process.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Maria Lopez: In the past two years, I was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, which was a big shock for me. I had always been careful with my diet, but I think the stress of juggling work, school, and family life caught up to me. I wasn't sleeping well, and I wasn't as active as I used to be. When I went to the clinic for my regular check-up, the doctor ran some tests and told me the news. At first, I felt overwhelmed, like I had failed my family in some way. But I knew I couldn't let this define me. I started seeing a nutritionist, and I've been working on adjusting my meals to include more whole foods and less processed sugar. I also started going to the gym a few times a week, even if it's just for thirty minutes. It's been a learning curve, but I'm grateful for the support from my family and my doctor. I've also started monitoring my blood sugar levels daily, and I've learned to listen to my body more. It's not always easy, but I know this is a part of my journey, and I'm determined to take care of myself so I can be there for my kids and my family for years to come.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Maria Lopez: It has been challenging, but I've learned to adapt. At first, managing my diabetes felt like another burden on top of everything else. There were days when I felt tired, or when I had to check my blood sugar before going to work, and I worried it would affect my ability to care for my kids. But I've come to see it as part of my responsibility—to take care of myself so I can take care of them. My husband has been incredible, reminding me to eat, to rest, and to not push myself too hard. I've also started setting reminders on my phone for medication and meals, which helps me stay on track. It's not perfect, and there are still days when I feel frustrated, but I know I'm doing the best I can. I've also started talking to other women in my community who have diabetes, and it's comforting to know I'm not alone in this. We share tips, encouragement, and sometimes just a laugh. It's a reminder that even in the hardest times, there's always a way forward—if you're willing to take it one step at a time.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Maria Lopez: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel like I'm making progress, and other days I feel like I'm just barely keeping up. Life has been busy, but in a good way. I've been able to focus more on my studies, which has given me a sense of purpose, and I've also been able to spend more quality time with my kids. I've noticed that they're growing up so fast, and I want to make sure I'm there for every moment. I've also been trying to be more patient with myself, especially with my health. There are still days when I feel overwhelmed, but I've learned to take things one step at a time. I've found comfort in my faith, in my family, and in the little things—like watching my kids laugh, or seeing my plants grow on the balcony. I know it's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the life I have and the people who support me. I believe that as long as I keep moving forward, no matter how small the steps, I'm on the right path.

Going through the interview questions about my recent changes and health made me reflect on how much I've grown over the past few years. Starting evening classes for my master's was a big step, one that required me to balance work, family, and school in a way I never had before. It wasn't easy, and there were days when I felt overwhelmed, but I kept reminding myself that this was for my children's future. It also made me think about my health—how I used to neglect it in the past, but now I'm learning to take it seriously. Managing my diabetes has been a challenge, but it's taught me the importance of self-care and listening to my body. I've come to see my health not just as something I need to manage, but as a part of my responsibility to my family. I'm still learning, and there are days when I struggle, but I'm proud of how far I've come. I know I'm not perfect, but I'm doing my best to be the best version of myself for my kids, my husband, and for me.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Maria Lopez: Honestly, I've had my moments of feeling overwhelmed, especially when I'm juggling so many responsibilities. There were times when I felt like I wasn't doing enough for my family or for myself. I remember one night, after a long day at work, coming home exhausted and just breaking down in tears. I felt like I was failing them, like I wasn't the strong, capable mother I wanted to be. But I've learned that it's okay to not be perfect. I've started talking to a counselor at the community center, and it's been really helpful. She's taught me how to recognize when I'm feeling anxious or depressed and how to take small steps to take care of myself. I also lean on my faith a lot—praying before I go to sleep, reading scripture, and finding comfort in knowing that I'm not alone in this. I still have bad days, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to ask for help when I need it. I believe that healing is a process, and I'm committed to walking through it, one day at a time.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Maria Lopez: For my family, it's been a mix of challenges and blessings. My husband has been my rock, always reminding me that we're in this together. He's taken on more responsibilities at home, especially when I'm in class or feeling overwhelmed with my health. The kids have been amazing too—they've learned to be more independent, and they know when to give me space or when to remind me that I'm their hero. My mother, even though she's far away, has been a constant source of strength. She sends me messages every day, and she always says, 'You're doing great, mi hija.' It's those little things that keep us going. We've had our tough moments, but I feel like we're all growing through this. I know we're not perfect, but we're learning, we're supporting each other, and that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Maria Lopez: For me, religion has always been a source of strength and comfort, especially during the hardest times. Being Catholic is not just about going to Mass on Sundays—it's about the values we live by, the prayers we say, and the hope we hold onto even when things feel impossible. My mother taught me that faith is not just about believing in God, but about trusting in the journey, even when you can't see the path ahead. I find peace in the rituals, in the rosary, in the way the church community comes together to support one another. It's also what helped me through my struggles in Miami, when I felt so lost and alone. I still have moments where I question or feel distant, but I always come back to the belief that God has a plan, and that I'm not alone in this life. My faith is what keeps me grounded, and I want my children to know that no matter what, there's always light to be found, even in the darkest moments.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Maria Lopez: I don't use social media much, to be honest. I find it overwhelming with all the noise and comparisons, and I prefer to keep my focus on my family and the real world around me. That said, I do use Facebook occasionally to stay in touch with my brother in Spain and my cousin Ana here in Miami. I post some photos of the kids or share updates about our life, just so they can see what we're up to. I also follow a few community pages that share local events, like the church calendar or neighborhood clean-up days. It's a small way to stay connected, but I don't want to get sucked into the endless scrolling. My mother once told me that the most important connections are the ones you make face-to-face, and I try to live by that. I think it's easier to be present for the people I love when I'm not distracted by a screen.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Maria Lopez: Honestly, I haven't really turned to social media for support, even during tough times. I know it's out there, and I've seen people share their struggles and find comfort in online communities, but I've always found my strength in the people around me—my family, my faith, and the close-knit community I'm part of. That said, there was one time when I was feeling really overwhelmed with school, work, and my health, and I did message a few friends on Facebook just to vent. It was a small thing, but it helped me feel less alone. I think the difference is that for me, support comes from real, face-to-face connections, not just likes or comments. I admire people who can find solace online, but I prefer to lean on the people I know and love in person. I know that's not always possible for everyone, and I hope that if someone out there is struggling, they can find the help they need, whether it's through social media or another way.

Going through the questions about my health and recent challenges has made me reflect on how far I've come and how much I've grown. It wasn't easy to face the diagnosis of type 2 diabetes, and there were moments when I felt like I was failing my family. But I've learned that taking care of myself is just as important as taking care of them. Starting evening classes for my master's was another big step, one that required me to balance work, family, and school in a way I never had before. It wasn't easy, and there were days when I felt overwhelmed, but I kept reminding myself that this was for my children's future. I've also come to understand that it's okay to struggle, to feel anxious or depressed, and to ask for help when I need it. My faith, my family, and the support from my community have been my anchors through it all. I know I'm not perfect, but I'm proud of how far I've come, and I'm determined to keep moving forward, one step at a time.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Maria Lopez: In the past year, my stress levels have definitely fluctuated, especially with everything I'm juggling—work, school, my health, and being a mom. There are days when I feel like I'm on autopilot, just trying to get through the day without falling apart. But I've also learned some new ways to cope. I've started journaling, even if it's just a few sentences before bed, to help me process my thoughts. I've also found that talking to my counselor has been a huge relief—she helps me see things from a different perspective and reminds me that it's okay to feel overwhelmed. I've also started incorporating more prayer into my day, especially when I feel like I'm losing my way. My faith has been my anchor, and I've come to realize that I don't have to have all the answers right away. I've also leaned more on my family, whether it's my husband helping with the kids or my cousin Ana just being there to listen. I think the biggest change is that I've stopped trying to be perfect and started embracing the messiness of life. It's not always easy, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to take things one day at a time.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Maria Lopez: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and the kids' school supplies. Rent is always the largest chunk of our budget—about a third of our income. We live in a two-bedroom apartment, and while it's not too bad for our family of four, it still takes up a lot. Groceries come in second, especially since we're trying to eat healthier now that I have diabetes. I've had to be more careful with what we buy, which can be expensive. The kids also need uniforms, books, and other materials for school, and that adds up. I also set aside money for my master's classes, which is another expense I didn't expect when I started. On top of that, there are the medications I need for my blood pressure and diabetes, and the co-pays for my doctor visits. It's tight, but we make it work. I try to budget carefully, track every dollar, and sometimes I have to say no to things that aren't essential. It's not easy, but I know that every sacrifice we make is for a better future for the kids. I also try to save a little each month, just in case something unexpected comes up. It's a constant balancing act, but I'm learning to be more organized and to ask for help when I need it—whether it's from my husband, my family, or the community programs that support us.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Maria Lopez: Last month, our household spent around $3,200, which is actually a bit higher than usual. Normally, we budget around $2,800 to $3,000 a month. The increase was mostly due to unexpected expenses—like a new air conditioner for the apartment, which was needed because the old one broke down, and some emergency repairs at home. We also had to pay for a few extra doctor visits for me, and I bought a new laptop for my master's classes since my old one was getting too slow. I try to keep track of everything in a spreadsheet, and it helps me see where the money is going. The biggest fixed costs are always rent, groceries, and the kids' school-related expenses. I also set aside a small amount each month for savings, even if it's just $50 or so. It's not much, but it gives me a sense of security. I know we're not wealthy, but we're managing, and that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Maria Lopez: We rent our home. It's a two-bedroom apartment in a building with a small courtyard where the kids can play when the weather is nice. Renting has always been the reality for us, especially since we're not U.S. citizens and it's harder to get a mortgage. But I like the flexibility it gives us—being able to move if we need to, or to upgrade when the time is right. I also know that owning a home is a goal for many people, but for now, renting is what works for our situation. We've been in this apartment for about two years, and while it's not perfect, it's comfortable, and it's where my kids have grown up. I try not to worry too much about the future of housing, because I know that as long as we have a roof over our heads and a safe place for the kids, we're doing okay.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Maria Lopez: Over the past year, our bills have definitely gone up and down depending on the season and what's going on in our lives. In the summer, for example, we had to pay more for air conditioning, and we also spent more on ice for the kids' drinks since it was so hot. In the winter, we used more electricity for heating, and we had to buy extra blankets and warm clothes for the kids. Then there's the holidays—Christmas and Hanukkah, for example, when we have to buy gifts, decorations, and sometimes even go out to dinner with family. Those are always bigger expenses. School also plays a role—when the kids start the school year, we have to buy new uniforms, books, and supplies, which can be a big hit on the budget. On the other hand, there are times when things are cheaper, like when we can buy seasonal produce or take advantage of sales. I've also noticed that our healthcare costs have gone up a bit over the past year, especially with my diabetes management. I have to buy more medication, test strips, and sometimes even pay for extra visits to the doctor. It's all part of life, and I've learned to plan for these fluctuations as best as I can, even if it's not always easy.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family has been through together and how important it is to lean on one another during tough times. Talking about my mental health and the challenges I've faced with stress, anxiety, and my diabetes diagnosis reminded me of how far I've come, but also how much I still have to learn. It was humbling to acknowledge that I'm not always the strong, capable mother I want to be, and that it's okay to ask for help. My family has been my greatest source of strength—my husband's unwavering support, my children's love and understanding, and my mother's constant encouragement. I also thought about how I've chosen to stay away from social media, not because I don't want to connect, but because I believe the most meaningful connections are the ones made in person. It's comforting to know that I don't need likes or comments to feel supported; I have the people I love right here, right now. These reflections have reminded me that healing is a process, and that I'm not alone in this journey. I'm grateful for the love, the faith, and the small, everyday moments that keep me going.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Maria Lopez: I try to save in small, consistent ways, even if it's not a lot. Every month, I set aside whatever I can—sometimes it's $50, sometimes more if I have a little extra after paying the bills. I keep that money in a separate savings account at the local bank, just for emergencies or something unexpected. I know it's not much, but it gives me peace of mind. I also save in another way—by being careful with what I buy. I make a list before going to the store, and I try not to impulse buy things I don't really need. I've learned that saving doesn't always mean having a lot; it's about being mindful and planning ahead. My husband helps too—he'll sometimes set aside money for the kids' birthdays or holidays so I don't have to worry about it. I know we're not rich, but I believe that even small savings add up over time, and that's what helps us stay afloat.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Maria Lopez: For me, saving has always been more about the rainy day kind of thing, just in case something unexpected happens. I know we're not in a position to save for a home right now, but I want to make sure we have a little cushion for emergencies—like if one of the kids gets sick, or if my car needs repairs, or if something else comes up. I also try to save a little for my master's program, just in case I need to buy books or pay for extra classes. It's not a lot, but I believe that even small steps matter. I've learned that saving isn't about having a lot—it's about being responsible and thinking ahead, even when life feels uncertain. I want my kids to grow up knowing that we can handle whatever comes our way, and I think that starts with being prepared, even in small ways.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Maria Lopez: My occupation has always been about providing for my family, whether it was working part-time at the store when I was younger or now working full time at the local grocery store. My most important duties are making sure the shelves are stocked, helping customers find what they need, and keeping the store running smoothly. I take pride in the work I do because it's not just about the paycheck—it's about giving my kids the stability they deserve. I've learned to be efficient, organized, and always ready to help others, whether it's a customer who needs assistance or a coworker who's having a tough day. I also try to lead by example, especially with the younger employees, showing them that hard work and dedication can lead to a better future. It's not always easy, but I believe that every task I do, no matter how small, contributes to the life I'm building for my family.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Maria Lopez: I usually work around 40 hours a week, though it can sometimes be a bit more depending on the store's needs. My schedule is Monday through Friday, from 7:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m., but I often stay a little later when there's a rush or when I need to finish up some tasks before leaving. On weekends, I sometimes take on extra shifts, especially if I need to cover some expenses or if the store is short-staffed. It's not always easy to work that many hours, especially when I'm also going to classes and taking care of the kids, but I've learned to manage my time as best as I can. I try to be efficient during my shifts so I can get home in time to be with my family, and I make sure to take short breaks when I can to recharge. It's a lot, but I know that every hour I work is helping build a better future for my children, and that gives me the strength to keep going.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Maria Lopez: Yes, I did have more than one job at times, especially when I was first starting out in Miami. After moving here, I worked part-time at a local store while also taking on odd jobs—like cleaning offices, babysitting for neighbors, or helping at community events—to make ends meet. It was exhausting, but I knew I had to be there for my mother and brother. Later on, when I started working full time at the grocery store, I took on evening or weekend shifts when I could, just to help with the bills. I also worked as a volunteer tutor for kids in the community center, which was something I really enjoyed. It gave me a sense of purpose beyond just earning money. Now, with my evening classes, I've had to be even more careful with my schedule, but I still take on extra hours when needed. It's not always easy, but I've learned that having multiple sources of income, even if they're small, can make a big difference in keeping our family afloat.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much I've grown in managing my stress, worry, and emotional challenges over the past year. It's been a journey of learning to be kinder to myself, to ask for help when I need it, and to find strength in the people around me. I used to feel like I had to be perfect, but now I understand that it's okay to struggle and that healing is a process. Talking about my monthly budget and how we make ends meet reminded me of the sacrifices my family and I make every day, but also of the resilience we've built together. I'm proud of how far we've come, even if it's not always easy. I know we're not perfect, but we're learning, we're supporting each other, and that's what matters most.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Maria Lopez: In total, our household made around $3,800 in the past month. That includes my full-time salary at the grocery store, some extra shifts I picked up on the weekends, and a small part-time gig tutoring a few kids in math at the community center. My husband also works as a mechanic, though his hours can be inconsistent depending on the shop's workload. We're lucky that both of us are working, and it helps us cover the basics—rent, groceries, the kids' school supplies, and my master's classes. It's not a lot, but it's enough to get by, and I feel grateful for every dollar we earn. I know we're not wealthy, but I believe that as long as we're working hard and supporting each other, we can keep moving forward.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Maria Lopez: I've been working at the grocery store for almost three years now, and it's become a big part of my life. The job doesn't come with many benefits, like health insurance or paid vacation days, which is something I've had to adjust to. I do get a small amount of sick time, and sometimes the manager is willing to be flexible if I need to take a day off for something important, like a doctor's appointment or a family emergency. I've learned to make the most of what I have—like using my sick days wisely and asking for time off when I really need it. I also appreciate the coworkers I've built relationships with over the years; they're like family to me. Even though the job isn't perfect, it's given me stability, and that's what matters most. I know I'm not in a position to demand more, but I hope one day, as I continue my education and build my career, I can find a job that offers more security and support for my family.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Maria Lopez: My relationships at work are mostly positive, even if they're not always perfect. I have a good relationship with my manager, Ms. Alvarez. She's fair, and while she can be strict when the store is busy, she also knows when to be understanding. She's given me some opportunities to take on more responsibilities, like training new employees, which I really appreciate. It's not always easy working under someone who has high expectations, but I know she's doing her job, and I try to meet those expectations as best as I can. As for my coworkers, we have a strong sense of camaraderie. We all work hard, and we look out for each other. There are days when things get tough, but we laugh, we support one another, and we make it through together. I've been there long enough that I feel like part of the team, and that makes a big difference. I know I'm not in a position to ask for much, but I'm grateful for the respect and the sense of belonging I've found at work.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Maria Lopez: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there are times when it can be a bit flexible depending on the store's needs. I usually work Monday through Friday from 7:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m., and I've come to rely on that routine because it helps me balance everything else in my life—school, family, and my health. That said, there are days when the manager asks me to stay a little later, especially during busy hours or when we're short-staffed. On weekends, I sometimes take on extra shifts, but it's not guaranteed. I appreciate the consistency of the schedule because it gives me a sense of control, especially with everything else going on. I know I can count on my days being the same most of the time, and that helps me plan for my classes, my kids' activities, and my own time to rest and recharge. It's not perfect, but it works for me.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Maria Lopez: Overall, I feel like we're managing, even if it's not always easy. There are days when I worry about the future, about whether we'll be able to afford everything my kids need, or if I'll be able to finish my master's without falling behind. But I also feel grateful for what we have—our home, our health, our family. I know we're not wealthy, but we're working hard, and that gives me hope. I believe that as long as we keep moving forward, even in small steps, we can build a better life for ourselves. I've learned to be proud of what we've accomplished so far, and I try not to let the uncertainty of the future overwhelm me. It's not perfect, but it's ours, and I'm doing my best to make it work.

Going through the questions about my bills, savings, and work schedule has made me reflect on how much I've had to adapt to make ends meet. It's not always easy to track every dollar, to plan for unexpected expenses, or to balance work, school, and family life, but I've learned that small, consistent efforts matter. I used to feel overwhelmed by the uncertainty of our financial situation, but now I see it as a part of our journey—one that requires resilience, planning, and support from the people around me. I'm proud of how we've managed to keep our heads above water, even when things feel tight. It's humbling to realize how much I've grown in learning to budget, save, and prioritize what's most important. I know we're not rich, but I'm grateful for the stability we've built and the strength it takes to keep moving forward.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Maria Lopez: Yes, my mother worked for pay while I was growing up, though it wasn't easy for her. She took on whatever job she could find—cleaning houses, working in factories, even doing piecework at home—to support my brother and me. She never had the chance to finish high school, and she always told me that education was the key to a better life. I remember her working long hours, sometimes coming home exhausted, but she never complained. She would sit with us at night, helping us with our homework, even though she didn't have much formal education herself. I think that's what taught me the value of hard work and perseverance. She didn't have much, but she gave us everything she could, and I'm so grateful for that. I carry her strength with me every day, and I hope to pass that same kind of resilience on to my children.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Maria Lopez: My mother worked as a house cleaner and also did some sewing work from home. She would clean for families in our neighborhood, sometimes working from morning until night, just to make sure we had food on the table and could afford to go to school. Her most important duties were always about providing for us—making sure we had clean clothes, something to eat, and that we were safe. Even when she was tired, she would sit with us and help us with our homework, teaching us the basics of reading and math. She didn't have much in the way of formal education, but she had a sharp mind and a strong will. I remember her telling me that she wanted more for me than she had, and that's what pushed me to work hard in school. She never complained about the long hours or the low pay, but she always made it clear that she was doing it for us. Her work was never glamorous, but it was everything to her, and I think that's what taught me the value of perseverance and sacrifice.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Maria Lopez: My mother worked for different families in our neighborhood, mostly as a house cleaner, and sometimes she did sewing work from home. She didn't have a formal job with a company or a business—she worked for whoever needed help, whether it was cleaning their homes, doing their laundry, or mending clothes. She would take on whatever work she could find, even if it meant working long hours or standing on her feet all day. She didn't make much, but she always made sure we had what we needed. I remember her telling me that she didn't have the luxury of choosing her hours or her work, but she did it because she wanted a better life for us. She never complained, even when she was exhausted, and that taught me the meaning of sacrifice. I think that's why I work so hard today—not just for myself, but for the life she never had, and for the future I want for my children.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Maria Lopez: A few years from now, I hope to be in a place where my family is safe, healthy, and happy. I hope my children are growing up with the same values I've tried to instill in them—hard work, kindness, and faith. I hope they're pursuing their dreams, whether that's going to college, starting their own families, or finding their own paths in life. For me personally, I hope I've finished my master's degree and that I'm in a position where I can help others the way I was helped when I was starting out. I want to be a role model, not just for my kids, but for the young women in my community who are trying to build a better life too. I also hope that my health is stable, that I'm taking care of myself the way I know I should, and that I'm still able to be there for my family. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I do know that as long as I keep working hard, staying strong, and believing in the power of love and perseverance, I can create a future that's full of hope, not just for me, but for all of us.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Maria Lopez: What I value the most in my life is my family—my husband, my children, and the love and support we share. I also value faith, because it has been my anchor through every challenge, and it reminds me that no matter how hard things get, there is always hope. I value education, because I know how much it can change a person's life, and I want my children to have the opportunities I fought so hard for. I also value resilience—the ability to keep going, even when life feels heavy. I've seen that in my mother, in my husband, and in myself. I value the small, everyday moments too—the laughter of my kids, the warmth of a good meal, the quiet moments of prayer. These things remind me that life is worth fighting for, and that even in the hardest times, there is beauty to be found.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my work has shaped my life and the sacrifices I've made to provide for my family. Talking about my current job at the grocery store reminded me of how grateful I am for the stability it provides, even though it doesn't come with many benefits. It also made me think about how far I've come from the days when I had to take on multiple jobs just to make ends meet. I've learned to appreciate the relationships I've built at work, the camaraderie with my coworkers, and the understanding I've developed with my manager. It's not always easy, but I know that every hour I work is helping build a better future for my children. I'm proud of the resilience I've shown, and I hope to one day be in a position where I can offer more security and support for my family, not just through hard work, but through education and opportunity.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, gratitude, and resilience. It reminded me of how far I've come—from a child in Seville, moving to a new country with nothing but hope, to the mother of two children in a community that feels like home. I've faced challenges that tested my strength, from financial struggles to health issues, but each step has been a lesson in perseverance. This interview made me realize how much my family, my faith, and the support of others have shaped who I am today. I'm proud of the life I've built, not because it's perfect, but because it's filled with love, hard work, and the belief that no matter how tough things get, there's always a way forward. I hope that by sharing my story, I can inspire others to keep going, to believe in themselves, and to never lose sight of the dreams that drive them forward.
